newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS - Australian bonds rally, outlook checkered.
newsitem.headline: RTRS - Australian bonds rally, outlook checkered.

text.p: *Australian bonds rallied sharply after Tuesday's aggressive futures-led sell-off as the market regrouped on current positive economic fundamentals.
*However, tone still cautious on U.S. market, Iraq crisis.

Australian bonds rallied sharply after Tuesday's aggressive sell-off as the market regrouped on current positive economic fundamentals, and generally shrugged off the absence of any Reserve Bank rates announcement.
However, the market is keeping a wary eye on developments in the U.S./Iraq conflict, although it showed no reaction to a second U.S. cruise missile attack on Iraq today.
"Both sides have played their pawns, and the question is what piece does Saddam Hussein move next?" said Stephen Roberts, chief economist at UBS Australia.
The inflationary implications of higher oil prices eminating from the Iraq crisis appeared to be brushed aside for now as the immediate focus concentrates on Friday's U.S. non-farm payrolls.

U.S. Treasuries rebounded on Tuesday on a more subdued than feared NAPM index and a soft Redbook retail sales report, but fears of a tightening by the Federal Reserve remain close at hand, traders said.

The local market went into near free fall yesterday amid the combination of the Iraq crisis, newspaper reports that the Fed is leaning towards a 50 basis point tightening and a sharp jump in local retail sales.
The Reserve Bank left monetary policy unchanged after Tuesday's board meeting, making no announcement at its money market operations time today.
This came as little surprise after yesterday's 2.4 percent leap in retail sales and given that the central bank had eased policy by 50 basis points only in July.
However, bill futures remained fairly jumpy in the run-up to the Bank's dealing time, but quickly eased back when no policy statement was made.
The active December bill futures contract ended at 93.16 after a day's high of 93.19. It had touched 93.35 on Tuesday.

The Australian/U.S. 10-year bond yield spread narrowed slightly after Tuesday's blow-out. This spread had got down to around 115 basis points on Monday when a firm local short end, on tentative rate cut hopes, had supported long bonds and briefly decoupled from a shaky U.S. market.

The 10-year bond futures contract rotated around 91.830 for most of the session after bouncing from 91.665 in after hours trade and having sustained a break back over 91.770. Immediate range seen between 91.700 to 91.900
